instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the backlight on the LCD screen, this is necessary to get the screen to light up..
definitions.LCDBKLT_BOOST: What is LCDBKLT_BOOST? LCDBKLT_BOOST is connected to the SWITCH(SW) pin of the LED driver and is switched to ground quickly after the inductor in the DC to DC boost circuit that boosts PPBUS_G3H to backlight voltage for the screen. .
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKLT_EN: What is BKLT_EN? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKLT” before “_EN”. “BKLT” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
System had water damage replace lcd connector a bunch of corroded components pertaining to lcd backlight. And ran some wires for broken traces on backlight boost. Replaced led driver im assuming if i had bridged any balls on led driver the system wouldnt turn on? I do get an image on screen and <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is high my only guess to why i dont get a backlight at this point is that <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> is not getting proper voltage?

<SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> = 8.56v
pin 3/4 of lcd connector get 8.56v
<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_BOOST</SIGNAL> = 8.56v
<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> = 2.8v

any ideas?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: First suspect would be the feedback trace to ball A5. PWM signal present? Bad soldering on <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Yes there was no continuity to ball a5 from feedback trace test poiny. it also came straight off when trying to add solder to it. Ill have to run a wire from test point of FB to A5 ball. PWM signal is present but at 1.4v

ill have to wait for my LED drivers to come in before i continue.

is it smart to try and dig out a pad on A5 or is it useless once it comes off?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: If A5 pad is gone it is best just to run a small wire.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
I replaced led driver again ran a small wire from a5 to <SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> since the FB trace was pretty useless. I get 8.5v on that wire now but i still get no backlight is it because <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> remains at 1.4v and <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> is at 2.8v? Im stumped at this point.

Update: found the issue i ran a wire to the wrong point removed and all is working. I do however get this theater light effect on the bottom right side of the screen also when turning the brightness down the left side gets darker than the right Its not a big deal but im wondering if its the screen itself from the water damage or the isens resistors at fault?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: One or more of the LED return lines are not good. Check <RESISTOR>R7717</RESISTOR>-22, could also be bad soldering on the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7717</RESISTOR> seems to be shorted to ground its trace goes under all the damage not sure if thats why? I removed it and it actually looks a lot better without it. Will there be an issue down the road without it?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: No idea, could be shorted under the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> or in the board of course. See if there is a GND ball next to the one <RESISTOR>R7717</RESISTOR> is going to. I think it should be ok to leave it as -is if the short is in the board. It will just look shit on the LCD.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Decided to leave it as is since it looks way better without it than before anyways.
